question: The following are possible concerns that researchers could have about Open Access publishing. Which of these concerns would you agree with?
value_1: Green OA (self-archiving): Some journals might not publish findings that are uploaded to a pre-publication archive
value_2: Green OA (self-archiving): Non-peer-reviewed findings might add noise to the literature
value_3: Green OA (self-archiving): Making my work available pre-publication might reduce the number of citations to the ultimately published work
value_4: Green OA (self-archiving): Availability of the pre-publication manuscript might highlight differences (e.g., errors in analysis, revisions to hypotheses) between the original conception of the research and the ultimately published work

question: The following are possible concerns that researchers could have about Open Access publishing. Which of these concerns would you agree with?
value_1: Green OA (self-archiving): Some journals might not publish findings that are uploaded to a pre-publication archive
value_2: Green OA (self-archiving): Other people might copy my research and publish it before I do
value_3: Green OA (self-archiving): Non-peer-reviewed findings might add noise to the literature
value_4: Green OA (self-archiving): Making my work available pre-publication might reduce the number of citations to the ultimately published work
value_5: Green OA (self-archiving): Availability of the pre-publication manuscript might highlight differences (e.g., errors in analysis, revisions to hypotheses) between the original conception of the research and the ultimately published work
value_6: Gold OA: Open Access journals might have lower quality articles
value_7: Gold OA: Open Access journals might not provide rigorous peer-review
value_8: Gold OA: I might not have enough funding to pay Article Processing Charges for Open Access journals
value_9: Gold OA: The impact of an Open Access publication might be low (e.g., few downloads and citations, low public engagement)

question: Is there anything else you would like to mention about Open Science practices?
value_1: I think it is really important to not pretend as if all research is social science that has a clear methodology. In philosophy for instance, but also in qualitative research that is not always the case. I think it is important to strenghten people's attitudes rather than impose very specific procedures that might then reproduce existing inequalities between different research practices.

question: Is there anything else you would like to mention about Open Science practices?
value_1: the largest problem with open access of your data 9especially survey data) is the risk that someone else takes the data and constructs quite different scales that violate the whole idea of the research. then you have the risk that someone publishes with the same data a completly different idea. And i also strongly dislike the fact that someone who is good in statitics takes the data for which no investments are made and then publishes. So in my view the researchers that collect the data should have veto power and be co-author

value_1: Green OA (self-archiving): Some journals might not publish findings that are uploaded to a pre-publication archive
value_2: Gold OA: Open Access journals might not provide rigorous peer-review

question: Is there anything you want to share with us regarding your experiences with Open Access?
value_1: Labour law implications of obliging staff to publish open access are currently not taken into account. This is highly problematic, especially as EUR staff must also provide open access for publications that do not (clearly or in the view of publishers) meet the requirements of article 25fa Auteurswet (as otherwise the UB will not include the publication in Pure). This is not correct and not goed werkgeverschap of the EUR. This element of open access is not given any attention at the moment. The one size fits all approach (such as: 6 months for all publications) of the EUR to open access is not in line with the legislative history of article 25 fa Auteurswet and does not take into account the differences between disciplines and their publishing cultures.

question: Is there anything else you would like to mention about Open Science practices?
value_1: Be aware of differences between disciplines, no one size fits all, inclusion in Pure should not be linked to open access, open access is a right of the employee and should not be turned into an obligation set by university on the employee (especially given that the EUR interprets article 25 Auteurswet so extensively, that employees are forced to break rules that publisher set. And please do note: article 25fa Aueteurswet does not apply if an emplyee has a contract with a foreign published under foreign law (we were told otherwise by the UB during an information session on open access, but that was legally incorrect information). And last bur not least: the EUR must be transparent on its open access obligations: why is the open access policy only accessible to employees and not to the outside world (including prospective employees who want to know what their obligations would be if they would become employees of the EUR? That does not fit with open access.

question: Is there anything you want to share with us regarding your experiences with Open Access?
value_1: I have read the university strives to publish all articles by EUR researchers as open access, but I am not aware of the details. I fully support this goal, as I do not understand how we can do research funded by tax payers and then have the findings behind pay walls.

value_1: Very important

value_1: I am aware of open data, materials, and/or code developed by others, but have not used them

question: Are you familiar with the FAIR principles for data and code?
value_1: Until now, I hadn't heard of the FAIR principles

question: The following are possible concerns that researchers could have about making data, materials, and/or code developed by them openly available. Which of these concerns would you agree with?
value_1: Others might criticise my data, materials, and/or code
value_2: Others might find it difficult to understand my data, materials, and/or code
value_3: Reuse of my data, materials, and/or code could violate the epistemological framework of my research
value_4: I might lose control over how my data, materials, and/or code are being used
value_5: It might take too much time, effort, and resources
value_6: Other_I am not sure if I have understood the epistemological framework of my research. What I mean is: in qualitative and quantitative data collection there are a lot of choices in the design that limit how the data can be interpreted. This knowlegde is gathered by the researcher during data collection. I find it hard to imagine that another researcher can skip that process and rely on my explanation of my data on FAIR principles and then use the data well. I think there is a high chance for error, that the data cannot be taken easily out of the broader data collection context and the purpose for which they have been collected. I think this is especially true for less structured interview data.

question: In your opinion, how important is preregistration for your work?

question: The following are possible concerns that researchers could have about preregistering their studies. Which of these concerns would you agree with?
value_1: I need to look at my data before I can decide how to best analyse it
value_3: Preregistration stifles research creativity or flexibility
value_4: Preregistration might lead to other people taking my research idea and implementing my plan
value_5: Other_My phd design has changed quite drastically at least four times due to practical data collection difficulties. I imagine preregistering would take a lot of time. In a way the ethical review already requires some sort of preregistering, although it is not publicly available. I think it is more important that in the design phase researchers work with professionals so that the design is aligned with what is possible in terms of data collection and also what type of questions are interesting from a practical/professional point of view (as complementary to the researchers non-practice informed view)
